TABLE 14.1RACIAL DIFFERENCES IN UNEMPLOYMENT RATES IN THE U.S., 1890–1930

TABLE 14.2RACIAL DIFFERENCES IN UNEMPLOYMENT RATES IN THE U.S. 1940–1989

Summarizing, analysis of three rather comprehensive surveys of individual unemployment experiences in the 1890–1930 period leads us to believe that racial differences in unemployment rates were essentially nonexistent. As table 14.1 indicates, the mean rate of unemployment for the three dates differs by only 0.08 percentage points between whites and nonwhites. In every case, the nonwhite-white unemployment ratio is between .92 and 1.17, suggesting that the similarities between the races in terms of unemployment were more striking than the differences.
THE UNEMPLOYMENT-RATE DIFFERENTIAL SINCE 1940
